description: From Middle English molesten, from Old French molester, from Latin molestō (“to trouble, annoy, molest”), from molestus (“troublesome”), from moles (“a burden, difficulty, labor, trouble”); see mole.

verbs.description: molest (third-person singular simple present molests, present participle molesting, simple past and past participle molested)

examples: They have molested the church with needless opposition.

entries.meaning: To sexually assault or sexually harass.
